contents.title: Christopher Noessel // Designing Agentive Technology // The Service Experience Conference 2017
contents.generated_title: Christopher Noessel // Designing Agentive Technology // The Service Experience Conference 2017
contents.description_html: Advances in narrow artificial intelligence make possible agentive systems that do things directly for their users (like, say, an automatic pet feeder). They deliver on the promise of user-centered design, but present fresh challenges in understanding their unique promises and pitfalls.

contents.title: LUNAVITY: A Backpack Multi-rotor for Jump Augmentation
contents.generated_title: LUNAVITY: A Backpack Multi-rotor for Jump Augmentation
contents.description_html: Web: https://lunavity.com/ Email: info@lunavity.com Lunavity is a system designed to augment the human capability of jumping. An attachable multi-rotor elevates the user during the movement, enabling them to leap higher and further. In the future, where drones are widely used for delivery and/or transportation, it can be applied to augment our mobility temporarily.
contents.description: Web: https://lunavity.com/ Email: info@lunavity.com Lunavity is a system designed to augment the human capability of jumping. An attachable multi-rotor elevates the user during the movement, enabling them to leap higher and further. In the future, where drones are widely used for delivery and/or transportation, it can be applied to augment our mobility temporarily.

contents.title: Kasita unveils prefabricated tiny houses that slot into "racks"
contents.generated_title: Kasita unveils prefabricated tiny houses that slot into "racks"
contents.description_html: An Austin-based startup has created a prototype of a prefabricated micro dwelling that can be slotted into a framework like a bottle into a wine rack (+ slideshow). The micro-housing startup called Kasita - adapted from the Spanish word for a small house - was launched by a professor-turned-entrepreneur who once lived in a dumpster.
contents.description: An Austin-based startup has created a prototype of a prefabricated micro dwelling that can be slotted into a framework like a bottle into a wine rack (+ slideshow). The micro-housing startup called Kasita - adapted from the Spanish word for a small house - was launched by a professor-turned-entrepreneur who once lived in a dumpster.

source.title: Kasita unveils prefabricated tiny houses that slot into "racks"

contents.title: Sensible Signage
contents.generated_title: Sensible Signage
contents.description_html: Future Cities Catapult has, in this film, captured six fictional use cases to describe just some of the ways that low energy signage technology might be used in parks, to tackle existing challenges, but also to create new opportunities and better, more liveable cities.

contents.title: Chinese tourist town is using facial recognition to allow entry
contents.generated_title: Chinese tourist town is using facial recognition to allow entry
contents.description_html: Wuzhen, a famous water-town in China, introduced the system this week Cameras can spot people and check whether they are registered But there have been concerns around the privacy of large databases of images used for facial recognition The days of having to remember to your ID with you could soon be a thing of the past.
contents.description: Wuzhen, a famous water-town in China, introduced the system this week Cameras can spot people and check whether they are registered But there have been concerns around the privacy of large databases of images used for facial recognition The days of having to remember to your ID with you could soon be a thing of the past.

source.title: Chinese tourist town is using facial recognition to allow entry

contents.title: Tech Totem - Teaser
contents.generated_title: Tech Totem - Teaser
contents.description_html: The Tech Totem is the first prototype of a distributed city experimentation platform, designed to: * Evaluate the impact of urban interventions * Allow business to easily deploy and test their technology in the city * Engage with inhabitants, capture local sentiment and sense the environment The tech totem provides a secure, powered space, where sensors or other devices can easily be fitted, for example, to collect data from the local environment, like air quality, noise or video analytics.
contents.description: The Tech Totem is the first prototype of a distributed city experimentation platform, designed to: * Evaluate the impact of urban interventions * Allow business to easily deploy and test their technology in the city * Engage with inhabitants, capture local sentiment and sense the environment The tech totem provides a secure, powered space, where sensors or other devices can easily be fitted, for example, to collect data from the local environment, like air quality, noise or video analytics.

source.title: Tech Totem - Teaser

embed.title: Tech Totem - Teaser

contents.title: Twelve Days in Xinjiang: How China's Surveillance State Overwhelms Daily Life
contents.generated_title: Twelve Days in Xinjiang: How China's Surveillance State Overwhelms Daily Life
contents.description_html: The government has turned the northwestern region into a laboratory for high-tech social controls. Citizens and visitors must run a daily gantlet of police checkpoints, surveillance cameras and machines scanning their ID cards, faces, eyeballs and sometimes entire bodies.
contents.description: The government has turned the northwestern region into a laboratory for high-tech social controls. Citizens and visitors must run a daily gantlet of police checkpoints, surveillance cameras and machines scanning their ID cards, faces, eyeballs and sometimes entire bodies.

source.title: Twelve Days in Xinjiang: How China's Surveillance State Overwhelms Daily Life

contents.title: Here are some of the ways experts think AI might screw with us in the next five years
contents.generated_title: Here are some of the ways experts think AI might screw with us in the next five years
contents.description_html: When we talk about the dangers posed by artificial intelligence, the emphasis is usually on the un intended side effects. We worry that we might accidentally create a super-intelligent AI and forget to program it with a conscience; or that we'll deploy criminal sentencing algorithms that have soaked up the racist biases of their training data.
contents.description: When we talk about the dangers posed by artificial intelligence, the emphasis is usually on the un intended side effects. We worry that we might accidentally create a super-intelligent AI and forget to program it with a conscience; or that we'll deploy criminal sentencing algorithms that have soaked up the racist biases of their training data.

source.title: Here are some of the ways experts think AI might screw with us in the next five years

contents.title: Artificial intelligence is going to supercharge surveillance
contents.generated_title: Artificial intelligence is going to supercharge surveillance
contents.description_html: We usually think of surveillance cameras as digital eyes, watching over us or watching out for us, depending on your view. But really, they're more like portholes: useful only when someone is looking through them. Sometimes that means a human watching live footage, usually from multiple video feeds.
contents.description: We usually think of surveillance cameras as digital eyes, watching over us or watching out for us, depending on your view. But really, they're more like portholes: useful only when someone is looking through them. Sometimes that means a human watching live footage, usually from multiple video feeds.

source.title: Artificial intelligence is going to supercharge surveillance

contents.title: China's Surveillance State Should Scare Everyone
contents.generated_title: China's Surveillance State Should Scare Everyone
contents.description_html: Even more worrying is that the government will be technically capable of considering the behavior of a Chinese citizen's friends and family in determining his or her score. For example, it is possible that your friend's anti-government political post could lower your own score.
contents.description: Even more worrying is that the government will be technically capable of considering the behavior of a Chinese citizen's friends and family in determining his or her score. For example, it is possible that your friend's anti-government political post could lower your own score.

source.title: China's Surveillance State Should Scare Everyone

contents.title: Interactions
contents.generated_title: Interactions
contents.description_html: There has been a revolution, but it snuck up on us so gradually that you'd be forgiven if you missed it. It's called artificial intelligence, and it will have a profound impact on how we design digital products in the near future. This has been something of an unexpected comeback.
contents.description: There has been a revolution, but it snuck up on us so gradually that you'd be forgiven if you missed it. It's called artificial intelligence, and it will have a profound impact on how we design digital products in the near future. This has been something of an unexpected comeback.

source.title: Interactions

contents.title: This robot reviews art better than most critics
contents.generated_title: This robot reviews art better than most critics
contents.description_html: Let's face it, robots are going to steal all our jobs. It'd be a tragedy if machines weren't already on course to be way better at what they do than we are. Case in point: the Novice Art Blogger, a Tumblr page set up by Matthew Plummer Fernandez.
contents.description: Let's face it, robots are going to steal all our jobs. It'd be a tragedy if machines weren't already on course to be way better at what they do than we are. Case in point: the Novice Art Blogger, a Tumblr page set up by Matthew Plummer Fernandez.

source.title: This robot reviews art better than most critics

contents.title: 50 trends shaping the future of civil society
contents.generated_title: 50 trends shaping the future of civil society
contents.description_html: Civil society is all of us, and the impact we all have on each other. A huge variety of factors shape how such a complex web of people, ambitions and circumstances plays out. What are these factors? What impacts might they have on the future lives of peop

contents.title: What does the panopticon mean in the age of digital surveillance?
contents.generated_title: What does the panopticon mean in the age of digital surveillance?
contents.description_html: The philosopher Jeremy Bentham famously requested in his will that his body be dissected and put on public display. This came to pass, and his skeleton now sits in a glass case at University College London, adorned with a wax head, waistcoat and jacket and sat on a wooden stool, staring out at students from its glass case.
contents.description: The philosopher Jeremy Bentham famously requested in his will that his body be dissected and put on public display. This came to pass, and his skeleton now sits in a glass case at University College London, adorned with a wax head, waistcoat and jacket and sat on a wooden stool, staring out at students from its glass case.

source.title: What does the panopticon mean in the age of digital surveillance?

contents.title: The invention of AI 'gaydar' could be the start of something much worse
contents.generated_title: The invention of AI 'gaydar' could be the start of something much worse
contents.description_html: Two weeks ago, a pair of researchers from Stanford University made a startling claim. Using hundreds of thousands of images taken from a dating website, they said they had trained a facial recognition system that could identify whether someone was straight or gay just by looking at them.
contents.description: Two weeks ago, a pair of researchers from Stanford University made a startling claim. Using hundreds of thousands of images taken from a dating website, they said they had trained a facial recognition system that could identify whether someone was straight or gay just by looking at them.

contents.title: UMii: Urban Innovation Mobility Index
contents.generated_title: UMii: Urban Innovation Mobility Index
contents.description_html: UMii aims to provide insights into urban mobility and innovation in cities across the world, and to deliver a guide for cities to foster innovation in their urban mobility services and systems. To find out more visit http://umi-index.org/

contents.title: Twelve Days in Xinjiang: How China's Surveillance State Overwhelms Daily Life
contents.generated_title: Twelve Days in Xinjiang: How China's Surveillance State Overwhelms Daily Life
contents.description_html: The government has turned the northwestern region into a laboratory for high-tech social controls. Citizens and visitors must run a daily gantlet of police checkpoints, surveillance cameras and machines scanning their ID cards, faces, eyeballs and sometimes entire bodies.
contents.description: The government has turned the northwestern region into a laboratory for high-tech social controls. Citizens and visitors must run a daily gantlet of police checkpoints, surveillance cameras and machines scanning their ID cards, faces, eyeballs and sometimes entire bodies.

source.title: Twelve Days in Xinjiang: How China's Surveillance State Overwhelms Daily Life

contents.title: Here are some of the ways experts think AI might screw with us in the next five years
contents.generated_title: Here are some of the ways experts think AI might screw with us in the next five years
contents.description_html: When we talk about the dangers posed by artificial intelligence, the emphasis is usually on the un intended side effects. We worry that we might accidentally create a super-intelligent AI and forget to program it with a conscience; or that we'll deploy criminal sentencing algorithms that have soaked up the racist biases of their training data.
contents.description: When we talk about the dangers posed by artificial intelligence, the emphasis is usually on the un intended side effects. We worry that we might accidentally create a super-intelligent AI and forget to program it with a conscience; or that we'll deploy criminal sentencing algorithms that have soaked up the racist biases of their training data.

source.title: Here are some of the ways experts think AI might screw with us in the next five years

contents.title: Artificial intelligence is going to supercharge surveillance
contents.generated_title: Artificial intelligence is going to supercharge surveillance
contents.description_html: We usually think of surveillance cameras as digital eyes, watching over us or watching out for us, depending on your view. But really, they're more like portholes: useful only when someone is looking through them. Sometimes that means a human watching live footage, usually from multiple video feeds.
contents.description: We usually think of surveillance cameras as digital eyes, watching over us or watching out for us, depending on your view. But really, they're more like portholes: useful only when someone is looking through them. Sometimes that means a human watching live footage, usually from multiple video feeds.

source.title: Artificial intelligence is going to supercharge surveillance

contents.title: China's Surveillance State Should Scare Everyone
contents.generated_title: China's Surveillance State Should Scare Everyone
contents.description_html: Even more worrying is that the government will be technically capable of considering the behavior of a Chinese citizen's friends and family in determining his or her score. For example, it is possible that your friend's anti-government political post could lower your own score.
contents.description: Even more worrying is that the government will be technically capable of considering the behavior of a Chinese citizen's friends and family in determining his or her score. contents.title: Interactions
contents.generated_title: Interactions
contents.description_html: There has been a revolution, but it snuck up on us so gradually that you'd be forgiven if you missed it. It's called artificial intelligence, and it will have a profound impact on how we design digital products in the near future. This has been something of an unexpected comeback.

contents.title: This robot reviews art better than most critics
contents.generated_title: This robot reviews art better than most critics
contents.description_html: Let's face it, robots are going to steal all our jobs. It'd be a tragedy if machines weren't already on course to be way better at what they do than we are. Case in point: the Novice Art Blogger, a Tumblr page set up by Matthew Plummer Fernandez.

contents.title: What does the panopticon mean in the age of digital surveillance?
contents.generated_title: What does the panopticon mean in the age of digital surveillance?
contents.description_html: The philosopher Jeremy Bentham famously requested in his will that his body be dissected and put on public display. This came to pass, and his skeleton now sits in a glass case at University College London, adorned with a wax head, waistcoat and jacket and sat on a wooden stool, staring out at students from its glass case.
contents.description: The philosopher Jeremy Bentham famously requested in his will that his body be dissected and put on public display. This came to pass, and his skeleton now sits in a glass case at University College London, adorned with a wax head, waistcoat and jacket and sat on a wooden stool, staring out at students from its glass case.

source.title: What does the panopticon mean in the age of digital surveillance?

contents.title: The invention of AI 'gaydar' could be the start of something much worse
contents.generated_title: The invention of AI 'gaydar' could be the start of something much worse
contents.description_html: Two weeks ago, a pair of researchers from Stanford University made a startling claim. Using hundreds of thousands of images taken from a dating website, they said they had trained a facial recognition system that could identify whether someone was straight or gay just by looking at them.
contents.description: Two weeks ago, a pair of researchers from Stanford University made a startling claim. Using hundreds of thousands of images taken from a dating website, they said they had trained a facial recognition system that could identify whether someone was straight or gay just by looking at them.

source.title: The invention of AI 'gaydar' could be the start of something much worse
